<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>After 20 months of avoiding Covid like a streaking soccer fan dodges security guards, it finally tackled me. On Friday I tested positive with mild symptoms, and now I’m cooped up in my NYC apartment for the next 10 days, a good chunk of which I’ll be off from work.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Here’s what went through my mind after the test came back:</p>
<ol style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>Seriously?</span></li>
<li><span>F***.</span></li>
<li><span>This is a huge buzzkill. No Colombia trip I had been planning with my brother.</span></li>
<li><span>I should text all the people I saw this week.</span></li>
<li><span>What the heck do I do now?</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">What <em>do </em>I do now? Once these symptoms die down, I suppose I could crank out three hours a day on the Peloton, get really in shape. Should I dive into articles on a new topic? Learn a new piano piece? Brainstorm 2022 work projects? Watch YouTube lectures?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This quarantine <em>feels</em> like a chance to get ahead. But after a long, stressful year, maybe it’s a better opportunity to…not do anything much at all. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Maybe the question I should really be asking is, is all the hype around <em>The Great British Baking Show </em>deserved? I will report back.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="#">Icebreakers With...Bloomberg Columnist Matt Levine
</a>
</h1>
<img alt="Matt Levine" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/32b29802a37efc9bfde4c78109bd4f1e7a77ab07-1024x646.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<span class="source" style="display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px"><small><em>Bloomberg</em></small></span>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Whenever we’re trying to grapple with a confusing new finance topic, whether it’s a SPAC, NFT, or the latest memecoin, there’s only one person we turn to: Matt Levine. The former lawyer/banker-turned-writer is perhaps the sharpest person currently writing about Wall Street, which he does every day in his Money Stuff newsletter for Bloomberg (<a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/account/newsletters/money-stuff?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sign up here</a>).</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We talked to Matt about all of the things.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You left banking for writing, saying you felt “alienated” from your labor. Do you think finance faces a brain drain as people look for more fulfilling, less stressful work?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I don’t know. I think it faces a brain drain as people go into tech. In particular I think that each year there is a cohort of young people who got good grades at a fancy college, are comfortable with algebra, are willing to work hard but don’t really have any clear idea of <em>what </em>they want to do, are very focused on money and prestige, and are not too troubled by moral qualms. Those people are always in high demand, and there is a shifting set of industries and companies that successfully recruit them. When I was in college, those people went to investment banks or to consulting firms. Now if you are smart, hard-working, expensively educated, directionless, and down for a certain amount of evil, I think you probably choose Facebook (sorry, Meta) over Goldman Sachs or McKinsey. Or you go into crypto, which is like finance but insane.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If you had to write about only one company for the rest of your career, what would it be?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Oh, Tesla. It just has everything. It is the original and greatest meme stock. It has a CEO who is constantly doing weird stuff online, including committing light securities fraud. Its approach to corporate finance is so strange yet oddly effective. It has wild corporate governance conflicts. It does battle with short sellers. It does vague crypto things.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Also I love writing imaginary dialogue for Elon Musk. I think he is wonderful because he is very smart and thinks interesting thoughts about legal stuff, but he is not a lawyer and sort of thinks the opposite way from how a lawyer thinks? So everything law-related that he does is wrong, but in a plausible and interesting way, and he is sure he’s right and has a big fight about it.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Give us a sense of your writing setup. Two monitors? Coffee? Music?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I mostly write from home, on a Mac desktop with one big monitor. Sometimes I go to the office, where I have a PC with two monitors and I get all the keystrokes wrong. I drink coffee. I subscribe to the Flow State newsletter and sometimes I put on their sort of ambient-ish music to write.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But mostly I have no repeatable process, I just wake up and panic until there’s a newsletter. I have been doing it long enough that the panic feels less overwhelming; I figure I have a good track record of producing a newsletter every day, so the odds that today’s the day it stops working are low. But I do text my friends most days saying “help I have nothing to write about” or “help I have forgotten how to write” or “help today’s the day it stops working.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Rate your excitement about living in the metaverse on a scale of 1–10 </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I don’t know what it is. I will say that I live a lot of my life on the internet and, like, in particular a lot of my life consists of inhabiting an online persona that is not exactly identical with my real self. So in some ways, you know, bring on the metaverse. But if it’s “Zoom meetings but with animated avatars,” then no thank you.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There’s so much more of the interview at <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/icebreakers-with-bloomberg-columnist-matt-levine?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this link</a>.</p>
</div>


</div>
</td>
</tr>

</h3>
<h1 class="sponsored-header__title" style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
There’s a Clear Trend: Successful Businesses Follow Trends
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<a style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N1196603.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26801247.319140704;dc_trk_aid=511605125;dc_trk_cid=160903053;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" class=""><img alt="Staples" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://media2.morningbrew.com/uploads/placement/images/4369/1639530269-CD5994_RTL_smb_cover_photo_TW_1500x500.jpg">
<div style="padding-left: 40px;">

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We’re not saying you have to stay on top of whether influencers are still wearing bucket hats, tiny sunglasses, or billowy jeans (tbh, we’re not sure). But we <em>are </em>saying the business world has trends of its own—and the savviest companies follow them closely. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But how, you ask? In partnership with Staples, <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N1196603.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26801247.319140704;dc_trk_aid=511605125;dc_trk_cid=160903053;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">we outlined</a> what trend-following looks like in practice. Because you don’t want to do the biz world equivalent of donning leg warmers or—*shudder*—low-rise jeans. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">To run a small business successfully, you don’t just have to be aware of the broader trends. You’ve got to turn them into effective on-the-ground strategy. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">All that takes intentional focus. With our pals at Staples, <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N1196603.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26801247.319140704;dc_trk_aid=511605125;dc_trk_cid=160903053;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">we’ve broken it down into five actionable steps</a>, so you can get trendy on the quick. It’ll work better than searching “how to make business good now,” we pinky-promise. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N1196603.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26801247.319140704;dc_trk_aid=511605125;dc_trk_cid=160903053;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Learn how to become more trend-focused here</a>. </p>

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/make-it-work-how-to-deal-with-nepotism-in-a-family-owned-business?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">When Your Job Is Too Much Like 'Succession"
</a>
</h1>
<a style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/make-it-work-how-to-deal-with-nepotism-in-a-family-owned-business?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class=""><img alt="Make it work image " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I work for a family-owned business, and there is a crazy amount of nepotism. Is there a way to deal with it, or should I just quit and move on?—<em>Jenny, NY</em></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Like many of you, I spend this time of year regaling in my favorite holiday classics. Like the one about Donner’s son, Rudolph, who nearly lost his assured spot in the family business on account of that shiny red nose. I won’t tell you how it ends, but suffice to say nepotism remains a touchy subject in the sleigh-guiding industry.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">While reports of a nepotistic North Pole may come as a shock, I’m a bit less surprised to hear that you’re encountering similar issues in your workplace. Unless leadership is committed to keeping such practices at bay (an outsourced HR function or a strong anti-nepotism policy are good indicators), even the most well-meaning family business can quickly find itself faced with the perception that its culture is exclusionary.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">While favoritism itself generally does not have any legal implications, keep in mind that could change if those actions are deemed to be discriminatory. Even on the right side of the law, “crazy nepotism” can negatively impact the experience of other employees and the success of the business. In this case, it <em>could</em> be worth having a conversation with a manager or someone you trust to share some careful, objective feedback—but realize that the risk of backlash is probably at least equal to the likelihood of meaningful change.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So, should you quit? Like nepotism, it’s all relative. If you’re being directly impacted by the culture and your growth opportunities within the company are limited, it’s likely in your best interest to move on. But remember that problems (including favoritism) can be found everywhere, so if you love this job otherwise and can compartmentalize being excluded from the occasional reindeer game, it may be worth trying to climb that family tree a bit longer.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Something bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</em></p>
</div>

<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>

</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/budweiser-nike-launching-nfts?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">Why 144-Year-Old Brands Are Launching NFTs
</a>
</h1>
<a style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/budweiser-nike-launching-nfts?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class=""><img alt="Why 144-Year-Old Brands Are Launching NFTs" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/47c8fcf82da277662009462174f6eda09cc8f909-1440x403.png?rect=122,0,1176,403&w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In late November, Budweiser popped open a cold one and took a foamy gulp of crypto, changing its Twitter name to beer.eth and launching an NFT (non-fungible token) project of 1,936 unique digital cans that sold out in minutes. The collection immediately soared in price on the secondary market. On OpenSea, the world’s largest NFT marketplace, the cheapest resales went for upwards of .5 ethereum ($2,200) and rarer cans for <a href="https://opensea.io/collection/budverse-cans-heritage-edition?search[sortAscending]=false&search[sortBy]=LAST_SALE_PRICE" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than $20,000.</a></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">To support its NFT launch, Budweiser has also adopted the conventions of Web3, a catch-all term encompassing innovation built on blockchain technology. Its Twitter account <a href="https://twitter.com/budweiserusa/status/1465425272241594381?s=20" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">traded memes</a> with crypto-influencers, it established a Discord community, and it pledged to holders of its NFTs that each “will act as an entry key to the Budverse, unlocking exclusive benefits, rewards, and surprises for…NFT holders." </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This is just the latest sign of Corporate America’s experimentation with crypto and its willingness to invest significant branding resources in those efforts.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">What other companies are getting into NFTs?</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The announcements have come fast and furious from corporate giants across a variety of sectors. </p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li>
<span>Nike </span><span><a href="https://news.nike.com/news/nike-acquires-rtfkt?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">acquired RTFKT,</a></span><span> a leading NFT and digital collectibles brand, to expand its digital capabilities, and Adidas launched a buzzy collaboration with Pixel Vault’s Punks Comic and Bored Ape Yacht Club, two of the world’s most successful NFT projects. It has also reserved a large plot of digital land in Sandbox, a fast-growing metaverse platform.</span>
</li>
<li><span>Time Magazine is producing a children’s TV show based on Robotos, a popular robot-themed NFT project.</span></li>
<li><span>The NBA’s Dallas Mavericks are rewarding fans who purchase tickets on Ticketmaster with exclusive NFTs commemorating their attendance.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">But why now?</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>1. The desire to get in early on a potentially massive technological paradigm shift.</strong> Many established companies of the last two decades were slow to take advantage of the internet and mobile technology, and they ended up losing significant market share to digitally native upstarts. By dipping their toes in early, big brands are hoping to be in a better position if crypto <em>does</em> turn out to be fundamental to the next wave of internet innovation.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>2. The brand-building and marketing opportunities.</strong> Crypto-native companies and influencers have tapped into the mimetic and fast-moving qualities of internet culture to build huge followings on social platforms, and brands see an opportunity to appeal to a new generation of consumers steeped in that world. By partnering with successful Web3 creators and establishing their crypto bonafides, legacy brands are attempting to position themselves as trendy innovators, even when their businesses remain focused on selling physical products and providing services in the “real” world. There is a delicate line to walk, though, since inauthentic-seeming launches are <a href="https://twitter.com/maxnorris__/status/1469097541992124425?s=20" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">getting panned by the crypto community.</a></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Big picture: </strong>These early steps into crypto by established corporations are clearly experiments to see what works and resonates with consumers, and there is no doubt that many will be chalked up as failures.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">However, as interest and participation in crypto-based technologies continue to pick up steam around the world, expect more brands to launch new projects to snag mindshare in this new market. As <a href="https://twitter.com/whitecastle/status/1469034170357854217?s=21" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">White Castle would say</a>, it’s probably nothing.—<em>MB</em></p>
</div>

#353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eAfter 20 months of avoiding Covid like a streaking soccer fan dodges security guards, it finally tackled me. On Friday I tested positive with mild symptoms, and now I’m cooped up in my NYC apartment for the next 10 days, a good chunk of which I’ll be off from work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHere’s what went through my mind after the test came back:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSeriously?\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eF***.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThis is a huge buzzkill. No Colombia trip I had been planning with my brother.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eI should text all the people I saw this week.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhat the heck do I do now?\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhat \u003cem\u003edo \u003c/em\u003eI do now? Once these symptoms die down, I suppose I could crank out three hours a day on the Peloton, get really in shape. Should I dive into articles on a new topic? Learn a new piano piece? Brainstorm 2022 work projects? Watch YouTube lectures?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis quarantine \u003cem\u003efeels\u003c/em\u003e like a chance to get ahead. But after a long, stressful year, maybe it’s a better opportunity to…not do anything much at all. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMaybe the question I should really be asking is, is all the hype around \u003cem\u003eThe Great British Baking Show \u003c/em\u003edeserved? I will report back.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n{if profile.signup_time \u003c time(\"-45 days\")}\n{if ! profile.click_time || profile.click_time \u003c time(\"-90 days\")}\n\u003c!-- CHURN MESSAGE ---\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"c6 core_hidden\"\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth class=\"card\" style=\"text-align:left;font-weight:normal;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333333;display:block;background-color:#F5F8FC;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;margin-bottom:15px;\"\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:0px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:15px;margin-bottom:15px;line-height:22px;margin-top:15px;margin-bottom:15px;line-height:22px;\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eREAD THIS TO REMAIN A SUBSCRIBER\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:15px;margin-bottom:15px;line-height:22px;margin-top:15px;margin-bottom:15px;line-height:22px;\"\u003eWant to keep receiving Morning Brew? width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/32b29802a37efc9bfde4c78109bd4f1e7a77ab07-1024x646.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eBloomberg\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhenever we’re trying to grapple with a confusing new finance topic, whether it’s a SPAC, NFT, or the latest memecoin, there’s only one person we turn to: Matt Levine. The former lawyer/banker-turned-writer is perhaps the sharpest person currently writing about Wall Street, which he does every day in his Money Stuff newsletter for Bloomberg (\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/account/newsletters/money-stuff?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esign up here\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe talked to Matt about all of the things.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou left banking for writing, saying you felt “alienated” from your labor. Do you think finance faces a brain drain as people look for more fulfilling, less stressful work?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI don’t know. I think it faces a brain drain as people go into tech. In particular I think that each year there is a cohort of young people who got good grades at a fancy college, are comfortable with algebra, are willing to work hard but don’t really have any clear idea of \u003cem\u003ewhat \u003c/em\u003ethey want to do, are very focused on money and prestige, and are not too troubled by moral qualms. Those people are always in high demand, and there is a shifting set of industries and companies that successfully recruit them. When I was in college, those people went to investment banks or to consulting firms. Now if you are smart, hard-working, expensively educated, directionless, and down for a certain amount of evil, I think you probably choose Facebook (sorry, Meta) over Goldman Sachs or McKinsey. Or you go into crypto, which is like finance but insane.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you had to write about only one company for the rest of your career, what would it be?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOh, Tesla. It just has everything. It is the original and greatest meme stock. It has a CEO who is constantly doing weird stuff online, including committing light securities fraud. Its approach to corporate finance is so strange yet oddly effective. It has wild corporate governance conflicts. It does battle with short sellers. It does vague crypto things.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAlso I love writing imaginary dialogue for Elon Musk. I think he is wonderful because he is very smart and thinks interesting thoughts about legal stuff, but he is not a lawyer and sort of thinks the opposite way from how a lawyer thinks? So everything law-related that he does is wrong, but in a plausible and interesting way, and he is sure he’s right and has a big fight about it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGive us a sense of your writing setup. Two monitors? Coffee? Music?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI mostly write from home, on a Mac desktop with one big monitor. Sometimes I go to the office, where I have a PC with two monitors and I get all the keystrokes wrong. I drink coffee. I subscribe to the Flow State newsletter and sometimes I put on their sort of ambient-ish music to write.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut mostly I have no repeatable process, I just wake up and panic until there’s a newsletter. I have been doing it long enough that the panic feels less overwhelming; I figure I have a good track record of producing a newsletter every day, so the odds that today’s the day it stops working are low. But I do text my friends most days saying “help I have nothing to write about” or “help I have forgotten how to write” or “help today’s the day it stops working.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRate your excitement about living in the metaverse on a scale of 1–10 \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI don’t know what it is. I will say that I live a lot of my life on the internet and, like, in particular a lot of my life consists of inhabiting an online persona that is not exactly identical with my real self. So in some ways, you know, bring on the metaverse. But if it’s “Zoom meetings but with animated avatars,” then no thank you.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere’s so much more of the interview at \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/icebreakers-with-bloomberg-columnist-matt-levine?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethis link\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- END SOCIAL LINKS - --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- END ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003c!-- SPONSORED SECTION --\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; font-size: 16px; font-weight: bold; line-height: 34px; letter-spacing: 0em; text-align: left; color: #1c7ff2; text-transform: uppercase;\"\u003e\nTOGETHER WITH STAPLES\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 class=\"sponsored-header__title\" style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nThere’s a Clear Trend: Successful Businesses Follow Trends\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N1196603.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26801247.319140704;dc_trk_aid=511605125;dc_trk_cid=160903053;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Staples\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://media2.morningbrew.com/uploads/placement/images/4369/1639530269-CD5994_RTL_smb_cover_photo_TW_1500x500.jpg\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"sponsored-body\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0 40px 40px 40px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe’re not saying you have to stay on top of whether influencers are still wearing bucket hats, tiny sunglasses, or billowy jeans (tbh, we’re not sure). But we \u003cem\u003eare \u003c/em\u003esaying the business world has trends of its own—and the savviest companies follow them closely. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut how, you ask? In partnership with Staples, \u003ca href=\"https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N1196603.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26801247.319140704;dc_trk_aid=511605125;dc_trk_cid=160903053;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewe outlined\u003c/a\u003e what trend-following looks like in practice. Because you don’t want to do the biz world equivalent of donning leg warmers or—*shudder*—low-rise jeans. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eTo run a small business successfully, you don’t just have to be aware of the broader trends. You’ve got to turn them into effective on-the-ground strategy. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAll that takes intentional focus. With our pals at Staples, \u003ca href=\"https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N1196603.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26801247.319140704;dc_trk_aid=511605125;dc_trk_cid=160903053;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewe’ve broken it down into five actionable steps\u003c/a\u003e, so you can get trendy on the quick. It’ll work better than searching “how to make business good now,” we pinky-promise. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N1196603.3407870MORNINGBREW/B26801247.319140704;dc_trk_aid=511605125;dc_trk_cid=160903053;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;ltd=\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eLearn how to become more trend-focused here\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- END SPONSORED SECTION --\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/make-it-work-how-to-deal-with-nepotism-in-a-family-owned-business?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Make it work image \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI work for a family-owned business, and there is a crazy amount of nepotism. Is there a way to deal with it, or should I just quit and move on?—\u003cem\u003eJenny, NY\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLike many of you, I spend this time of year regaling in my favorite holiday classics. Like the one about Donner’s son, Rudolph, who nearly lost his assured spot in the family business on account of that shiny red nose. I won’t tell you how it ends, but suffice to say nepotism remains a touchy subject in the sleigh-guiding industry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhile reports of a nepotistic North Pole may come as a shock, I’m a bit less surprised to hear that you’re encountering similar issues in your workplace. Unless leadership is committed to keeping such practices at bay (an outsourced HR function or a strong anti-nepotism policy are good indicators), even the most well-meaning family business can quickly find itself faced with the perception that its culture is exclusionary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhile favoritism itself generally does not have any legal implications, keep in mind that could change if those actions are deemed to be discriminatory. Even on the right side of the law, “crazy nepotism” can negatively impact the experience of other employees and the success of the business. In this case, it \u003cem\u003ecould\u003c/em\u003e be worth having a conversation with a manager or someone you trust to share some careful, objective feedback—but realize that the risk of backlash is probably at least equal to the likelihood of meaningful change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo, should you quit? Like nepotism, it’s all relative. If you’re being directly impacted by the culture and your growth opportunities within the company are limited, it’s likely in your best interest to move on. But remember that problems (including favoritism) can be found everywhere, so if you love this job otherwise and can compartmentalize being excluded from the occasional reindeer game, it may be worth trying to climb that family tree a bit longer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSomething bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/make-it-work-how-to-deal-with-nepotism-in-a-family-owned-business\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/budweiser-nike-launching-nfts?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\"\u003eWhy 144-Year-Old Brands Are Launching NFTs\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/budweiser-nike-launching-nfts?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Why 144-Year-Old Brands Are Launching NFTs\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/47c8fcf82da277662009462174f6eda09cc8f909-1440x403.png?rect=122,0,1176,403\u0026w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn late November, Budweiser popped open a cold one and took a foamy gulp of crypto, changing its Twitter name to beer.eth and launching an NFT (non-fungible token) project of 1,936 unique digital cans that sold out in minutes. The collection immediately soared in price on the secondary market. On OpenSea, the world’s largest NFT marketplace, the cheapest resales went for upwards of .5 ethereum ($2,200) and rarer cans for \u003ca href=\"https://opensea.io/collection/budverse-cans-heritage-edition?search[sortAscending]=false\u0026search[sortBy]=LAST_SALE_PRICE\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than $20,000.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eTo support its NFT launch, Budweiser has also adopted the conventions of Web3, a catch-all term encompassing innovation built on blockchain technology. Its Twitter account \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/budweiserusa/status/1465425272241594381?s=20\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etraded memes\u003c/a\u003e with crypto-influencers, it established a Discord community, and it pledged to holders of its NFTs that each “will act as an entry key to the Budverse, unlocking exclusive benefits, rewards, and surprises for…NFT holders.\" \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis is just the latest sign of Corporate America’s experimentation with crypto and its willingness to invest significant branding resources in those efforts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eWhat other companies are getting into NFTs?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe announcements have come fast and furious from corporate giants across a variety of sectors. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eNike \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://news.nike.com/news/nike-acquires-rtfkt?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eacquired RTFKT,\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e a leading NFT and digital collectibles brand, to expand its digital capabilities, and Adidas launched a buzzy collaboration with Pixel Vault’s Punks Comic and Bored Ape Yacht Club, two of the world’s most successful NFT projects. It has also reserved a large plot of digital land in Sandbox, a fast-growing metaverse platform.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTime Magazine is producing a children’s TV show based on Robotos, a popular robot-themed NFT project.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe NBA’s Dallas Mavericks are rewarding fans who purchase tickets on Ticketmaster with exclusive NFTs commemorating their attendance.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eBut why now?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e1. The desire to get in early on a potentially massive technological paradigm shift.\u003c/strong\u003e Many established companies of the last two decades were slow to take advantage of the internet and mobile technology, and they ended up losing significant market share to digitally native upstarts. By dipping their toes in early, big brands are hoping to be in a better position if crypto \u003cem\u003edoes\u003c/em\u003e turn out to be fundamental to the next wave of internet innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e2. The brand-building and marketing opportunities.\u003c/strong\u003e Crypto-native companies and influencers have tapped into the mimetic and fast-moving qualities of internet culture to build huge followings on social platforms, and brands see an opportunity to appeal to a new generation of consumers steeped in that world. By partnering with successful Web3 creators and establishing their crypto bonafides, legacy brands are attempting to position themselves as trendy innovators, even when their businesses remain focused on selling physical products and providing services in the “real” world. There is a delicate line to walk, though, since inauthentic-seeming launches are \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/maxnorris__/status/1469097541992124425?s=20\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egetting panned by the crypto community.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThese early steps into crypto by established corporations are clearly experiments to see what works and resonates with consumers, and there is no doubt that many will be chalked up as failures.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHowever, as interest and participation in crypto-based technologies continue to pick up steam around the world, expect more brands to launch new projects to snag mindshare in this new market. As \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/whitecastle/status/1469034170357854217?s=21\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWhite Castle would say\u003c/a\u003e, it’s probably nothing.—\u003cem\u003eMB\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/17/budweiser-nike-launching-nfts\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
